description:
The Ministry of Education has announced that from the week of the 27th July 2020 Secondary Schools, Junior Colleges and Millenia Institutes may resume Lower-risk Co-Curricular Activities (CCAs) and other School activities with SMMs in place.

Primary schools may resume such activities at a later date, once the MoE has been able to assess the progress for the older students.

CCA’s may take place with the following SMMs in place.
 
Maximum of 20 students per activity and where possible, the composition of participants should be fixed to minimise inter-mingling. 

Within the activity, groups of five or fewer students can interact more closely. 

Modified game rules will apply, such that students will be at least one-metre apart, even for physical activities; and


Schools will continue to screen all visitors, including coaches and instructors, for flu-like symptoms such as fever and cough, and ensure that they comply with all SMMs.

CCA’s and school activities that include the following will not be permitted. 

High level of body contact, like Taekwondo sparring or Rugby scrum;
High exposure to aerosol and splatters, like playing of wind instruments or choir;

Inter-mingling of students between schools; and

Activities held at external venues.

description:
The Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Singapore Examinations Assessment board (SEAB), announced that adjustments will be made to the release of exam results pertaining to the 2020 national examinations to account for the safeguarding and wellbeing of staff and students. This was announced on the 27th October 2020.

Arrangements will be made for students to collect exam results in person from their teachers on the day of their release. Candidates are expected to observe Safe Management Measures (SMM’s), sign in via SafeEntry and screened for fever or flu-like symptoms. The results will be collected in small groups in individual classrooms.
Given the younger age of PLSE candidates, one parent or guardian is permitted to accompany the candidate, they must follow SMMS’s and not permitted on school premises for the retrival of the results, having to wait in the school’s common areas instead. 
SEAB has enhanced its systems so candidates can view their examination results online on the day of their release, via SEAB’s result release system on its website.
Candidates who cannot retrieve their results in person should view their results online and not go into school grounds to retrieve the physical copy. They may appoint a proxy to collect the physical results in addition to administrative forms (Secondary Option 1, Join Admissions Exercise, Polytechnic Foundation Programme or Joint Intake Exercise from). if a proxy is unable to be arranged then a specific arrangement may be made

description:
Singapore's Ministry of Health has introduced a vaccine injury financial assistance programme for the COVID-19 vaccination (VIFAP). In the event that an individual suffers serious side effects which assessed to be related to the COVID-19 vaccine the following shall be provided. 

1) A one time pay-out of up to $10,000 if they hospitalised requiring care in the High Dependency or Intensive Care Unit but subsequently recover from medically serious side effects. 

2) A one time pay-out of $225,000 to an individual who dies or suffers from a permeant severe disability as a result of COVID-19 vaccination. 

To qualify an individual must be 
1) a Singapore citizen 

2)  a permeant resident or long term pass holder who has received the COVID-19 vaccination in Singapore, and

3) experienced a serious side effect that is potentially life-threatening or fatal and has required inpatient hospitalisation or has caused persistent incapacity or disability. 

the severity of the side effects must be assessed by a doctor linked to the individual's COVID-19 vaccination. VIFAP applications will be assessed by an independent clinical panel set up the MOH.

2) essential personnel in critical functions such as those safeguarding law and order e.g. ICA officers who responsible for border controls, and those responsible for the supply water, energy, telecommunications, essential food services and essential household items.
 3) migrant workers living in dormitories, beginning with 10,000 workers who have never been infected and who are living in the five largest dormitories.

description:
Singapore's Ministry of Health has stated that as more vaccine supplies arrive they will consider allowing Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents early access to vaccinations in very exceptional circumstances.

such circumstances include 

A) Those who have to travel overseas for work or education (Formal or Vocational) where remote learning or working is impossible.

B) Those who wish to travel overseas to visit or care for a critically ill family member, or to seek medically necessary treatment which cannot reasonably be obtained in Singapore.

C) Those who would be more vulnerable due to having complex chronic medical conditions, which could lead to sever complications if they were to catch COVID-19.

those in A) and B) are required to fill out an application form, and it is recommended they do so eight weeks in advance of their plans commencing. priority will be given to those traveling to higher risk countries or regions.

Those with chronic conditions should have a discussion with their doctor to determine whether they are eligible for the vaccination based on their circumstances.

description:
Singapore's Ministry of Health has introduced a vaccine injury financial assistance programme for the COVID-19 vaccination (VIFAP). In the event that an individual suffers serious side effects which assessed to be related to the COVID-19 vaccine the following shall be provided. 

1) A one time pay-out of up to $10,000 if they hospitalised requiring care in the High Dependency or Intensive Care Unit but subsequently recover from medically serious side effects. 

2) A one time pay-out of $225,000 to an individual who dies or suffers from a permeant severe disability as a result of COVID-19 vaccination. 

To qualify an individual must be 
1) a Singapore citizen 

2)  a permeant resident or long term pass holder who has received the COVID-19 vaccination in Singapore, and

3) experienced a serious side effect that is potentially life-threatening or fatal and has required inpatient hospitalisation or has caused persistent incapacity or disability. 

the severity of the side effects must be assessed by a doctor linked to the individual's COVID-19 vaccination. VIFAP applications will be assessed by an independent clinical panel set up the MOH.

UPDATE: Applications for the Vaccine Injury Financial Assistance Program for COVID-19 Vaccination (VIFAP) will be open from March 17th 2021. 

the Ministry of Health emphasizes that VIFAP is meant only as an additional layer of financial support, and not to reimburse medical costs.

description:
From 18 September onwards, Individuals who are informed of their HRW and HRA status by MOH through SMS notification will receive instructions on the frequent testing regime they must follow. 

Individuals who receive an HRW SMS notification must get an entry polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test at a Swab and Send Home (SASH) Clinic or Private Practitioner (PP), and self-isolate until they receive a negative result from their first PCR test. they will also be required to perform self-administered ART tests on the third, fifth and seventh day from the day of last exposure to the COVID-19 case whom they were close contacts with, followed by another exit PCR test on or after the eighth day at a SASH clinic or PP. If all are complied with, their HRW period will end on tenth day of exposure. 

Individuals who receive HRA SMS notification should perform self-administered ART test on the first, third, and fifth day from the day of last exposure to the COVID-19 case whom they were potentially close contacts with, and monitor their health until the tenth day of exposure. Those on HRA are advised to exercise social responsibility and limit their interactions with other persons during that period.

description:
With effect from 10 October 2021, the Singapore government will be switching to the Home Recovery Programme (HRP) as the default care management model for the majority of COVID patients. 
There will no longer be issuing of Quarantine Orders. Instead, Singapore will issue a revised Health Risk Warning (HRW) to close contacts of COVID cases, including their household members. 

Under Health Risk Warning (HRW), close contact of COVIDpatients including family members will receive an HRW SMS.  Those under HRW are legally required to take an ART self-test within 24 hours and self-isolate immediately until you test negative. If you need to leave your house, you must do an ART self-test once a day before leaving your house during the 7-day HRW period.
If you test ART negative, you can leave your house for normal activities. Do minimise unnecessary social interactions. You must still complete the 7-day monitoring period.

description: On 12 May, Ministry Of Health announced that it has set up the Testing Operations Centre (TOC) to aggregate the national testing demand and centrally manage the allocation of testing capacity. This ensures that critical national needs are met, and will help laboratories manage workloads so that capacity is not overwhelmed by sudden surges in demands. We seek our laboratories’ cooperation in working closely with the TOC to achieve this. Laboratory testing is a critical enabler of the fight against COVID-19. It supports clinical diagnosis so that appropriate treatment can be provided to those who are unwell. It also enables active case finding and regular community surveillance, so that community transmissions can be ringfenced quickly to prevent the formation of large clusters. Testing is also currently used in a targeted way to monitor and protect vulnerable groups such as our seniors, healthcare workers and frontline officers managing COVID-19 cases. A robust and coordinated testing strategy will allow them to safely and gradually resume economic and community activities after the circuit breaker period.

description: From 17 June 2020, 2359 hours, all incoming travellers entering Singapore will be tested for COVID-19. Each person under SHN will receive an SMS notification informing them of the scheduled appointment slot and venue.We will not automatically swab all persons who are aged 12 or younger before the end of their SHN, as we recognise that the tests could pose difficulties for young children. However, if any of their close contacts are found to be positive, we will initiate the swab tests for them.Persons on SHN may only leave their residence for the scheduled COVID-19 test appointment at the designated testing facility. They will have to travel from their place of residence to the designated testing facilities, and return immediately after the test, using their own private vehicle or pre-booked taxi. description:
The Ministry of Health of Singapore announced on 24 March tighter measures to minimise further spread of COVID-19, all congregational worship and religious services will be suspended from 26 Mar 2020, 2359 hrs to 30 Apr 2020.

During this period, places of worship may remain open for essential rites (e.g. weddings and funerals) and private worship, subject to a cap of 10 persons at any one time and with the precautionary measures listed in the Annex. Much as we understand the desire of friends and acquaintances to pay their last respects and give comfort to families in their grief, we ask religious leaders to advise their followers on the need to minimise physical interactions even during funerals and wakes.
If necessary, non-congregational activities involving 10 or fewer people (e.g. religious classes, cell group meetings) may be held with the precautionary measures in the Annex. Religious leaders should advise their followers to adhere to similar measures, even if such activities are not held on the premises of the religious organisation.
The limit of 10 persons at any one time does not apply in workplace situations in places of worship where religious and administrative staff/volunteers are performing their duties (e.g. providing pastoral services, setting up live streams of religious services). However, the number of workers involved should be kept to a minimum and limited to essential duties. 
UPDATE
As of April 3 places of worship are closed UPDATE: Announced April 3, religious services will remain suspended. Places of worship will be closed.
